metadata.copyright_compliance: Original content based on general medical knowledge

statement.text: Popliteal-tibial bypass connects the popliteal artery to a tibial vessel using autogenous vein, providing limb salvage for CLTI patients with combined femoropopliteal and tibial disease when adequate popliteal inflow exists.
statement.formal: Inflow: Above or below knee popliteal; Outflow: AT, PT, or peroneal; Conduit: Autogenous vein mandatory; Patency: 60-70% at 5 years with vein

explanation.intuition: When the popliteal artery has good flow but disease blocks the tibial arteries, a shorter bypass from the popliteal to a tibial vessel can restore blood flow to the foot. Using a short segment of vein from a healthy popliteal inflow improves durability.
explanation.key_insight: A short popliteal-tibial bypass with vein often outperforms a long femorotibial bypass - 'the shorter the better' principle for distal bypasses.
explanation.technical_details: Popliteal-tibial bypass uses the popliteal artery as inflow when it is free of hemodynamically significant disease. The bypass targets whichever tibial vessel provides the best outflow to the wound angiosome. Above-knee popliteal inflow is preferred when available, though below-knee popliteal can serve. Autogenous vein is mandatory - great saphenous vein is first choice, with arm veins or spliced conduit as alternatives. Reversed or in-situ vein techniques may be used.
common_misconceptions: Longer bypasses are better for durability - FALSE, shorter bypasses have better patency
Prosthetic conduit is acceptable for tibial targets - FALSE, vein is mandatory
Any tibial vessel is equivalent - FALSE, angiosome targeting matters
Below-knee popliteal inflow is inadequate - FALSE, can be excellent inflow source

anterior_tibial.exposure: Anterior compartment, lateral to tibial crest

peroneal.indication: Lateral heel wounds, no other target

prosthetic.exception: None - prosthetic should not be used

exposure.outflow: Appropriate tibial exposure based on target

completion.angiography: Mandatory to assess flow and anastomoses

definition.@value: Autogenous vein bypass from popliteal artery to tibial vessel for limb salvage in CLTI with preserved popliteal inflow.

presentation: CLTI with rest pain or tissue loss
Patent popliteal artery with tibial occlusive disease
Failed or unsuitable for endovascular treatment
diagnosis: CTA/MRA showing popliteal inflow and tibial disease
Vein mapping to identify adequate conduit

sources.reference: SVS Practice Guidelines for Lower Extremity Bypass

learning_objectives: Explain why shorter bypasses have better outcomes
Select appropriate tibial target based on angiosome
Describe vein conduit requirements and alternatives
clinical_pearls: Shorter bypass = better patency; use popliteal inflow when available
Autogenous vein is MANDATORY for tibial targets - no prosthetic
Vein diameter >3mm associated with better outcomes
Target the angiosome feeding the wound
Complete angiography or duplex is mandatory

medicalCode.name: Atherosclerosis of native arteries of leg with rest pain
